comments.commentBody: I don't even know who Jones is, but he sounds like an absolute nitwit.

Every community must start to realize that the Commons belong to all of us, and that we are all dependent on good management of our natural resources -- water, sand, oil, and many other things that are ultimately finite in supply.

And we need to realize that when we start placing an economic value on these resources, we can collect Natural Public Revenue, which will permit us to reduce the taxes on wages and sales and buildings and other evidence of production.

Read George: Henry George. He asserted that the Earth belongs to all of us in common. Observing that fact and conforming our policies and economic structures to it leads to a sustainable economy and society and environment in which all can prosper. Pretending it isn't so leads to environmental degradation and wealth concentration.

Which sort of community, society, world do you want to live in? Which do you want to leave to your children and grandchildren?

Read George. Henry George. There's plenty online.

As Mr. McMullin indicates, the nation is now at the crossroads: Disruption Junction at the corner of Dysfunction Square.

If we "normalize" President Trump and his wrecking crew, we promote:

1. Disrespect for the Constitution and laws of the United States;

2. The refusal to accept the legitimacy of one's political opponents;

3. Public officials' refusals to respect the people who disagree with them and the condoning of officials who deny a fair hearing to critics' claims;

4. Diminishment of the media's right to communicate the facts and its duty to keep the citizenry informed;

5. The failure of public office holders to bear the responsibilities of public office with dignity;

6. Infidelity to facts and recourse to frequent distractions, falsehoods, and outright lies in order to manipulate the public;

7. The abandonment of customary practices that insure some degree of transparency on the part of public officials and the hiding of public officials' potential conflicts of interest beneath layers of opacity;

8. Disrespect for the members of the judiciary;

9. Nepotism and cronyism;

10. The condoning of public officials who are avaricious, self-servingly ambitious and vengeful;

11. An authoritarian assault on democratic freedom;

12. A thoroughgoing coarsening of sensibilities.

Over two centuries ago, John Adams warned American citizens:

"[A]varice, ambition, [or] revenge . . . would break the strongest cords of our constitution as a whale goes through a net."
It would seem that in the person of 45, we have all three of Adams' traits that would "break the strongest cords of our constitution."  Avarice, ambition, revenge--God help us.

It was that important during the 2016 presidential election. Trump had made clear where he headed. Yet McMullin not only did not support the Democratic nominee, he was among several 3rd party candidates who contributed to her loss. We can't count on his predictions of his future votes. His past speaks for itself. He--and the FBI director, and possibly the Russians are why we have arrived at this ParlourSteakandFish state. However, President Obama's failure to speak up against the latter two probably played a greater role than McMullen's candidacy did.  (My blame of President Obama pre-dates the election. I'm surprised an deeply regretful that it wasn't shared by enough people to encourage him to seize his opportunity to seize his own opportunity to demonstrate his own Profile in Courage.) This election offered us a choice between preserving our republic or elevating someone ignorant of government and history and therefore subject to being led by the worst advisors bigotry and anti-Americanism could produce. We know how the election ended, but the results of a Trump presidency were predictable long before Election Day.
Apologies for not catching autocorrect and redundancy resulting from submitting from my cell phone.

This article and many of the comments make me happy to be a septuagenarian with limited time left on the planet. They also make me sad for what humanity has evolved into—if, indeed, this has been evolution—I think at some point we reversed our forward momentum.

The Earth is a beautiful planet and our species has had the opportunity to develop our intellect and live peaceful, harmonious lives, enjoying the fruits of who- or whatever put the mega-universe together. Instead we have polluted our nest and denied the reality of our mortality. Homo sapiens sapiens, my foot.

At some point we will become just another extinct species, having produced an environment that will no longer support higher life forms. I trust the planet will survive, and I hope lower forms of life will continue.

If there is life on other planets, in other solar systems, I hope it has evolved differently than we have. I think planet Earth deserves an A+ for providing such a nice home and for putting up with us. I think we, on the other hand, have failed miserably. We should have read Mary Shelly's Frankenstein more carefully.

There is an article in the Guardian today about Mr. Sessions where they detail how he prosecuted sometimes spurious cases against political rivals in Alabama. This piece of work has been at it for a long time.

https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/04/jeff-sessions-legal-past...

Well done, Minster.

Your father is a peach of a guy.

Always love the acrostics, and this one was among the better ones. I had to look, look again, chew on things, catch mistakes, recreate some things that had taken a while to build, and finally reach some nice Aha! moments.

Early gimmes: PIE CHART, TORTOISE, and EUREKA, with on-holds ACETATES, NIGHTWEAR, NOBELIST, and YPRES.

Most troublesome error: VOLTE-FACE before VICE VERSA. Other sillinesses on my part: Went blank on GATE LEG (well, at least I put the LEG part in). NEEDLEFISH took too long (but I did remember our old friend the GAR); Couldn't remember NEWSGROUP. Stuff like that.

Quite enjoyed the clue for LEMON PEEL, although I'm not a big James Bond fan.

And delighted to learn a new word: OPSIMATH.

Thanks for a wonderful puzzle. I so enjoyed it.
One more thing that distinguishes Jason:  He has fabulous taste and was smart enough to know a wonderful woman when he met her.  Thinking of you both.

This is one of the most beautifully touching articles I have read in a long, long time.  I send my prayers to Amy and thank you for sharing your life, your heart and your story with us. And for Jason, I send my love, as I fear he will have a much harder time as you, Amy, sound incredible.  Both (the article and your intention for your husband's future) are loving, open, gracious and noble in spirit and you have left my heart flayed wide open for eternity without even setting eyes on you once.  We should all live our short, gloriously lucky days here on earth as generous as you have here.

Like others commenting here and thousands more who read your beautiful essay, I wept. And then I began reading Encyclopedia of An Ordinary Life and stayed up all night, unable to put it down. It was a bittersweet experience, smiling at your astute insights and observations, yet always cognizant of the challenges you face now.
Like others, I will pray for a miracle. In the meantime, I hope you find comfort knowing how much you've enhanced the lives of those who know you in life and those who know you on the page.

Amy, my partner of almost ten years suddenly lost his wife to cancer in 2005. Our life together has been lovely, but yet, his name is still etched beside hers on their headstone in the local cemetery, and my last loving act for him will be to ensure that he his buried beside her, as he wished. My grief will be complicated. You, too, will be loved and cherished, and if Jason chooses a next partner, he will assure that you will rest sweetly and well, and his partner will kindly oblige him.

What a beautiful tribute to your husband, Amy. I should not be surprised as your books are full of beauty, too.  Thank you for sharing this part of your life with us. I hope it turns out to 'be' longer and fuller than you can imagine.
Life is a beautiful dance
If that's what you took from this beautifully written piece you've completely missed the point.
Jason sounds so much like the husband I lost five years ago that if I thought I had a chance, I'd volunteer. My hope is that he will find someone who will appreciate him as much as you have.

Mary, Valerie Harper was on her own path, too, and she had only weeks to live, according to what I read.  She is still with us.  Same with former president Jimmy Carter.  Both have had malignant brain cancers for a very long period of time now.  Is there something wrong with hoping and praying for something good?  I do not respect negativity, even when it seems to be warranted.  It doesn't help anyone.
And it is kind, decent, and RIGHT, to keep hoping for miracles...and that Amy should have one, and so should her family.  I will keep praying.  It sure doesn't hurt to keep hoping and praying.

until 2 years ago I was an assistant professor at Cornell in NYC and prior to that taught a Boston University. Yale requires a thesis for medical school - care to restate your opinion?

Medical care should be based on studies not anecdotes and sad stories. While ovarian cancer is heart breaking ultrasounds show no benefit even in high risk populations let alone as a screening tool in all women as you carelessly suggest.

Amy, Amy, Amy -- I will love you forever and for every good thing, word, and hug, I have had from you, and so much more.  These wonderful tributes and expressions make it clear the world loves you. I love you, too.  With so many loving, heart felt comments from the universe, you know those known to you and unknown have you in their collective hearts.  Me, too. I will miss you forever and will be left with so much I have learned from you. Love always, Ellie
I think like this too.  What Dreams May Come.

Yulia...this is just not nice. I am so sorry for the loss of your child, but what Amy wrote is not "dirty laundry." What she wrote was beautiful, dignified, and touched/touches the heart of many compassionate people.

AMY: NEVER GIVE UP!
Oy...vey.  Some of you people I just don't get.

Lisa, unfortunately, mental illness is an invisible disease. In order to live, you have to keep it in control which usually necessitates hiding your disease. Therefore, most people will not see it and will certainly not be moved to empathize.
But terminal cancer is overt – people see it clearly. It is something that touches people and they are especially touched when the sufferer shows bravery in the face of it all.
It takes bravery to endure mental illness as well, but no one will applaud you. I, however, do applaud you and understand.
Regarding Amy’s piece, I found it to be beautiful and my heart breaks for her. But I also know that people with mental illness (the “invisible” disease) can have lives even more heartbreaking than many of those whose lives are cut short by cancer.
I see why you think you will get lots of hostile replies to your comment. If you do receive them, however, it is because most people do not understand.

After reading many of the comments I now believe it's time for our nation to start taxing the churches. They certainly exert political influence. This debate should be based on proven facts, not religion. We can all share the facts, we do not all share the smoke and mirrors of religion.
Amen. ;)
